journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Optimal vibration control of smart composite beams with optimal size and location of piezoelectric sensing and actuation

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanics, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia
2Department of Aeronautics, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia

author-notes.corresp: Nemanja D Zorić, Department of Mechanics, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Belgrade, Kraljice Marije 16, Belgrade, 11120, Serbia. Email: nzoric@mas.bg.ac.rs

abstract.p: Control performances of smart structures depend on the size and location of the piezoelectric actuators and sensors as well as on the applied control algorithm. This article presents optimal vibration control of a thin-walled composite beam by using the fuzzy optimization strategy based on the particle swarm optimization algorithm. The optimization of the size and location of the conventionally collocated piezoelectric actuators and sensors, and optimization of the controller parameters are performed separately. The optimization criteria for optimal size and location of piezoelectric actuators and sensors are based on eigenvalues of the controllability Grammian matrix. The optimization procedure implies constraint of the original dynamic properties change and limitation of the beam mass increase. The particle swarm optimization-based linear quadratic regulator has been implemented for optimal vibration control in order to maximize the modal closed-loop damping ratios and minimize the control voltages required for actuation while keeping them below breakdown voltage for the used piezoelectric actuator. A pseudo-goal function, derived from the fuzzy set theory, gives an expression for global objective functions eliminating the use of weighting coefficients and penalty functions. The problem is formulated using the finite element method based on the third-order shear deformation theory. Several numerical examples are presented for the cantilever beam.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Thin-walled composite structures are widely applied in aerospace industry for designing aircraft wings and tails, wind turbine blades, and helicopter blades. The appearance of unwanted vibrations of these structures can lead to catastrophic failure (Worden et al., 2003). In order to control vibrations of the thin-walled structures during operation, conventional structures have been combined with the sensing and actuating mechanism to develop the so-called “smart structures.” Recent years have witnessed a great number of researches performed by using piezoelectric materials as distributed actuators and sensors (A/Ss) for active vibration control. The design process of smart structures involves three main phases, namely, structural design, optimal size and location of A/Ss, and controller design.

The dynamic performance and functionality of smart structures depend on the control algorithm. There are numerous control algorithms that can be applied for vibration suppression of thin-walled structures with distributed piezoelectric A/Ss. A comprehensive review of control algorithms applied for vibration suppression was presented by Alkhatib and Golnaraghi (2003). The classical control algorithms—direct proportional feedback/constant gain velocity feedback (CGVF)/constant amplitude velocity feedback (CAVF) control were employed by other researchers (Wang et al., 2001; Narayanan and Balamurugan, 2003; Lee et al., 2004; Yang et al., 2005; Vasques and Rodrigues, 2006; Zabihollah et al., 2007; Kumar and Narayanan, 2007, 2008; Kapuria and Yasin, 2010a, 2010b). The CAVF and CGVF control algorithms require collocated A/Ss to be stable. In the case of asymmetric angle-ply composites, stability is guaranteed only when the A/Ss are truly collocated due to the effect of the stretching–bending coupling (Kapuria and Yasin, 2010a, 2010b; Wang et al., 2001). Control effectiveness offered by direct proportional feedback is insignificant compared to the CGVF. Some researchers presented the linear quadratic regulator (LQR) optimal control approach for active vibration suppression (Bruant et al., 2001; Kapuria and Yasin, 2010a, 2010b; Kumar and Narayanan, 2007, 2008; Narayanan and Balamurugan, 2003; Roy and Chakraborty, 2009a; Vasques and Rodrigues, 2006; Zabihollah et al., 2007) and the linear quadratic Gaussian (LQG) algorithm (Dong et al., 2006; Kapuria and Yasin, 2010a, 2010b; Narayanan and Balamurugan, 2003; Vasques and Rodrigues, 2006). It has been found that the LQR control approach is effective in vibration control giving optimal control gain by minimizing the performance index; also, this algorithm does not require collocated A/Ss to be stable, but it does require the measurement of all state variables. Weighting matrices [Q] and [R] are the most important components of the LQR control algorithm since their combinations have great impact on controller performances. Both the CGVF and the optimal LQR and LQG control algorithms are studied for single-input–single-output (SISO) as well as multi-input–multi-output (MIMO) configuration. Qiu et al. (2007) have proposed positive position feedback (PPF) control, proportional–derivative (PD) control, and control strategy that combines PPF and PD. Wang and Inman (2011) have performed experimental and numerical comparison of four control systems (PPF, proportional-integral-derivative [PID], nonlinear control, and LQR) based on energy consumption.

The piezoelectric A/Ss have to be dimensioned and located properly since their size and location have great influence on the controllability and observable properties of a system as well as control performances (Frecker, 2003; Gupta et al., 2010). Two approaches are dominant in the A/Ss size and location optimization problems: the closed-loop and the open-loop approach. The closed-loop approach combines the optimal size/location of piezoelectric A/Ss and controller parameters whereas some studies (Bruant et al., 2001; Dutta et al., 2011; Kumar and Narayanan, 2007, 2008; Wei et al., 2010; Yang et al., 2005) considered a performance index to minimize the total energy stored in the system. An optimal location of A/Ss based on the maximization of the H2 norm is employed by Gawronski (2000), Halim and Moheimani (2003), Liu et al. (2006), and Dhuri and Seshu (2007). The second commonly used approach (open-loop) considers the optimal size/location of A/Ss independently of the controller definition with the maximization of controllability/observability using Grammian matrices (Bruant et al., 2010; Hac and Liu, 1993; Jha and Inman, 2003), the modal controllability index (Dhuri and Seshu, 2006, 2009; Roy and Chakraborty, 2009a, 2009b; Wang and Wang, 2001), or the modal electromechanical coupling (Bourisli and Al-Ajmi, 2010).

It can be noticed that these investigations are focused mainly on the size/location of the piezoelectric A/Ss for maximum control effectiveness. The natural frequency spectrum of the parent structure is affected by the integration of the piezoelectric patches. In case of active system failure, this change of dynamic properties might become significant (Dhuri and Seshu, 2006, 2007, 2009). Besides that, increase of the structure mass cannot be ignored especially in aerospace structures. Some earlier works (Dhuri and Seshu, 2006, 2009) considered change of natural frequencies through objective function in multi-objective optimization.

In recent years, a significant number of researches have applied heuristic optimization algorithms for solving optimization problems related to the active vibration control. Many studies have used the genetic algorithm (GA) for finding optimal size and location of A/Ss and optimal controller parameters (Bruant et al., 2010; Dhuri and Seshu, 2007; Jha and Inman, 2003; Kumar and Narayanan, 2007, 2008; Roy and Chakraborty, 2009a, 2009b; Wei et al., 2010; Yang et al., 2005). Roy and Chakraborty (2009a) have used integer-coded GA for optimal placement of actuators and real-coded GA to optimize matrices [Q] and [R]. Some works (Dhuri and Seshu, 2009; Hau et al., 2006) use the multi-objective GA (MOGA). The simulated annealing (SA) algorithm can also be used to determine the location of piezoelectric patches in order to maximize the actuators’ efficiency in feedback control (Moita et al., 2006). The particle swarm optimization (PSO) technique is proposed by Montazeri et al. (2008) and Marinaki et al. (2011) for optimization of the control system for vibration suppression of smart structures, and by Zorić et al. (2012) for optimal size and location of A/Ss.

This article deals with LQR-based optimal vibration control of cantilever composite beams using the fuzzy optimization strategy based on the PSO algorithm. The main idea of this optimization technique is the transformation of both objective functions and constraints into pseudo-goal functions through a process of fuzzification, converting the multi-objective optimization problem into a single-objective one by using the fuzzy decision principle proposed by Bellman and Zadeh (1970) and finding the optimal configuration with the help of the PSO algorithm. The beam has been modeled with the third-order shear deformation theory (TSDT) and discretized using the finite element method (FEM). The size and location optimization of the conventionally collocated piezoelectric A/Ss (Kapuria and Yasin, 2010b) as well as the optimization of the controller parameters are performed separately. The optimization criteria for size and location of conventionally collocated piezoelectric A/Ss are based on the eigenvalues of controllability Grammian matrix. The optimization process is performed by constraining the original dynamic properties change including the limitation of mass increase. In most of the existing literature, which has used the LQR control algorithm for optimal vibration control, matrices [Q] and [R] were selected by the trial and error method. There are very few researches dealing with optimization of matrices [Q] and [R]. Roy and Chakraborty (2009a, 2009b) have used GAs to optimize these matrices. The next objective of this article is to optimize matrices [Q] and [R] using the proposed optimization technique (PSO-based LQR or PSO-LQR) in order to maximize the modal closed-loop damping ratios by minimizing control voltages required for actuation and keeping them below breakdown voltage for the used piezoelectric actuator. Several examples are considered for the cantilever beam. The results obtained using this optimization technique are then compared with the corresponding results in the cases of simple placement of A/S and conventional optimal controller in order to show effectiveness of the proposed technique.

sec.title: Equations of active vibration control
sec.p: The laminated composite beam with integrated piezoelectric sensors and actuators considered here is presented in Figure 1. The coordinate x is coincident with the beam axis, the x−y plane coincides with the midplane of the beam, and the z axis is defined as normal to the midplane according to the right-hand rule. Both the elastic and the piezoelectric layers are supposed to be so thin that a plane stress state can be assumed. The sensors and actuators are perfectly bonded on upper and lower surfaces at different locations along the length of the beam. It is assumed that they span the entire width of the beam. The elastic layers are obtained by setting their piezoelectric coefficients to zero. The equivalent single layer theory is used, so the same displacement field is considered for all layers of the beam. The formulation results in a coupled finite element model with mechanical (displacements) and electrical (potentials of piezoelectric patches) degrees of freedom.

caption.p: Laminated composite beam with piezoelectric sensors and actuators.

sec.title: Coupled equations of motion
sec.p: After the finite element discretization (Appendix 1), global equations of motions can be written in terms of the nodal mechanical and electrical degrees of freedom as

where [M] represents the mass matrix; [Km] represents the elastic stiffness matrix; [Kme]A and [Kme]S are piezoelectric stiffness matrices of the actuator and sensor, respectively; [Ke]A and [Ke]S are dielectric stiffness matrices of the actuator and sensor, respectively; {ϕ}A and {ϕ}S are voltages sensed by actuator and sensor, respectively; {ϕ}AA is the vector of external voltage applied to actuators; and {Fm} is the vector of external forces. The following equation of motion can be obtained from equation (1)
where
represents the coupled stiffness matrix.

sec.title: Modal analysis
sec.p: For practical implementation, the obtained model needs to be truncated, where only first few modes are taken into account. Thus, the displacement vector can be approximated by the modal superposition of first r modes as
where [Ψ] represents the modal matrix, and {η} the vector of modal coordinates. Using equation (4), equation (2) can be transformed into the reduced modal space as
where [ω2] represents the diagonal matrix of the squares of the natural frequencies, and
represents the modal damping matrix, in which ζi is the natural modal damping ratio of the i-th mode.

sec.p: Equation (5) can be expressed in the state-space form as

where [CS] represents the output matrix that depends on the modal matrix and sensor piezoelectric stiffness matrix.

sec.title: Optimization criteria for piezoelectric actuator sizing and location
Controllability
sec.p: Controllability is a function of system dynamics and the location, size, and number of actuators. A structure is controllable if the integrated actuators excite all structural modes of interests. The controllability of the whole system is a combination of controllability of individual modes. A standard check for the controllability of a system is a rank test of controllability matrix [S] that has the following form (Inman, 2006)

The system is completely state controllable if and only if matrix [S] is full rank. The controllability of a system expressed by controllability matrix [S] indicates whether the system is controllable or not. The controllability can be expressed quantitatively by using controllability Grammian matrix defined as (Hac and Liu, 1993)
In modal coordinates, controllability Grammian is diagonally dominant (Hac and Liu, 1993)
and each diagonal term of controllability Grammian matrix can be expressed in a closed form eliminating time dependence of the solution

where (B¯)i is i-th row of matrix [B¯]. The value of WCii gives information about the energy transmitted from the actuators to the structure for the i-th mode. In other words, larger i-th eigenvalue of controllability Grammian matrix leads to smaller control efforts for suppression of the i-th mode. Consequently, if any eigenvalue of controllability Grammian is very low, the corresponding mode is very difficult to control and would require a huge energy for suppression.

sec.title: Objective functions
sec.p: This section formulates the objective functions for optimal sizes and locations of the conventionally collocated piezoelectric A/S pairs. The sizes and locations of conventionally collocated piezoelectric A/S pairs should be such that they give good controllability for the controlled modes. In order to control each mode by applying minimal control effort, each eigenvalue of controllability Grammian matrix has to be maximized. Since an optimal size and location of the actuator for one mode may not be optimal for the others, the optimization problem becomes multi-objective where objective functions are
where NC represents the number of controlled modes.

sec.title: Constraints
sec.p: The first type of constraints are related to the change of natural frequencies of controlled modes and increase the structure mass

where ωinew denotes the natural frequency of the i-th mode of the beam with piezoelectric patches, ωiold denotes the natural frequency of the i-th mode of the beam without piezoelectric patches, εfi is the change of the i-th natural frequency of the beam after integrating A/Ss, εfimax is tolerance of the i-th natural frequency change, mnew denotes the mass of the beam with piezoelectric patches, mold denotes the mass of the beam without piezoelectric patches, εm is the change of the beam mass, and εmmax is the tolerance of the change of the beam mass.
The second type of constraints is the geometric constraints that can be expressed as follows

list-item.p: Dynamic constraints that avoid overlap of piezoelectric patches

sec.p: where xi is the distance between the left side of the i-th piezoelectric patch and the fixed side; li is the length of the i-th piezoelectric patch; and NP represents the number of A/S pairs. Figure 2 schematically illustrates the cantilever beam with conventionally collocated A/S pairs, showing the positions and lengths of the i-th and the (i+1)-th piezoelectric patch.

caption.p: Positions and lengths of the i-th and the (i+1)-th piezoelectric patch on the cantilever beam.

sec.title: Fuzzy optimization strategy by pseudo-goal function
sec.p: In this section, a fuzzy optimization approach based on the pseudo-goal function for multi-objective problem is proposed (Huang et al., 2006; Sakawa, 2002). The objective functions (equation (17)) that have to be maximized, can be written as a pseudo-goal function in the form of the fuzzy number

where WCiimin and WCiimax denote the minimum and maximum i-th eigenvalue of WC, respectively; μWi(p) represents the membership function of the i-th objective function; and p represents the design variables set. Since WCiimin=0, equation (22) becomes
The membership function of the i-th objective function is presented in Figure 3.

caption.p: Membership function of the i-th objective function.

sec.p: The constraints may also receive the same fuzzification process as the objective functions. The membership functions of the first type of constraints, given by equations (18) and (19), are

where μfi(p) represents the membership function of the change of the i-th natural frequency of the beam, μm(p) represents the membership function of the change of the beam mass, while β¯fi and β¯m can be defined as fulfillment of the constraints (Zhang and Liu, 2008). The membership function of the change of the i-th natural frequency of the beam and membership function of the change of the beam mass are presented in Figure 4.

caption.p: Membership functions of constraints: (a) the i-th natural frequency change and (b) change of the beam mass.

sec.p: The membership function of the geometric constraints is

mml:mrow.mml:mtext: if geometric constraints are not violated

sec.p: According to the fuzzy decision principle (Bellman and Zadeh, 1970), the fuzzy decision is defined as the intersection of fuzzy objectives and fuzzy constraints. Thus, the optimum solution p* can be selected by maximizing the smallest membership function
where
represents the membership function of the optimal decision function.

sec.title: Optimization implementation using PSO
sec.p: The inspiration for the PSO came from the social behavior of animals such as fish schooling, insect swarming, and birds flocking. It was introduced by Kennedy and Everhart (1995). The system is initialized with a population of random solutions (called particles). Each particle represents a potential solution of the problem and is treated as a point in an m-dimensional space. For given i-th particle, its position is represented as (pi)=(pi1pi2⋯pid⋯pim) in which every coordinate represents a parameter that has to be optimized, and m represents the number of these parameters. The current position of every particle is affected by three factors: its own velocity (vi)=(vi1vi2⋯vid⋯vim), the best position it has achieved (best local position) that is determined by the highest value of the objective function encountered by this particle in all its previous iterations, and overall best position achieved by all particles (best global position), which is determined by the highest value of the objective function encountered in all the previous iterations. A particle changes its velocity and position in the following way

where χ is the inertia weight, c1 is the cognition factor, c2 is the social learning factor, r1 and r2 are random numbers between 0 and 1, the superscript k denotes the iterative generation, n is the population size, and finally, lbest and gbest are the best local and global position of the particle, respectively. The cognition factor and social learning factors are usually set as c1=c2=1.5. Perez and Behdinan (2007) give upper and lower limits of inertia weight for the structural design.

In the case of sizing and location of piezoelectric patches, each A/S pair is determined with two parameters: position, which represents the distance from the root of the beam (x) and its length (l). These two parameters for each A/S pair are presented in Figure 2. In this work, the beam is discretized into finite elements, so the position of an A/S pair is defined by the number of elements between the left side of the A/S pair and the fixed side, while the position of the left node and length are defined by the number of elements covered by this pair. The discretized beam is depicted in Figure 5. The minimal length of the piezoelectric patch is equal to the length of one element, and the number of finite elements directly affects the size and position of the A/S pair. According to the above, coordinate pi(2j−1) of the i-th particle represents the position of the j-th A/S pair, and coordinate pi(2j) represents the length of the j-th A/S pair. Figure 5 shows the positions and lengths of the j-th and the (j+1)-th piezoelectric patches presented as coordinates of the i-th particle. It is obvious that the coordinates of the particle and corresponding velocity are integer numbers. Because of that, the discrete method must be used. The velocity is updated by the following equation on every iteration (Jin et al., 2007)

caption.p: Positions and lengths of j-th and (j+1)-th piezoelectric patch after discretization presented as coordinates of the i-th particle.

sec.p: in which int() is getting the integer part of the function. Since the obtained optimal solution gives information about the size and position of A/Ss in a form of numbers of finite elements, it must be converted into real dimensions as follows
where (popt) represents the position of the particle that corresponds to the optimal solution.

sec.title: Model validation
sec.p: The aim of this section is to validate the developed computer code based on theoretical formulations discussed in the previous sections by comparing its numerical results with the experimental and numerical results of other researchers. The following validations for structural and electromechanical responses have been performed.

sec.title: Structural validation
sec.p: In order to validate the developed finite element code, cantilever symmetric laminated beam (0°/90°/0°)S with graphite–epoxy layers is considered. The material properties of the graphite–epoxy layer and dimensions of the beam are given in Table 1. The beam is discretized into 50 elements and the derived results are then compared with the experimental and numerical results based on the layerwise theory obtained by Zabihollah et al. (2007). These results are presented in Table 2. It can be observed from Table 2 that the results obtained from the present finite element code are in close agreement with the experimental results and the numerical results based on the layerwise theory.

caption.p: Material and geometric properties of the laminated beam for structural validation.
Comparison of natural frequencies between results obtained by Zabihollah et al. (2007) and the present FEM.

sec.title: Electromechanical validation
sec.p: In order to validate the developed coupled electromechanical finite element code, a piezoelectric bimorph cantilever beam constructed of two polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) bonded together is considered (modulus of elasticity: Y=2GPa, shear modulus: G=0.775GPa; Poisson’s ratio: ν=0.29; piezoelectric constant: e31=0.046C/m2; permittivity constant: k33=0.1062nF/m). The beam is shown in Figure 6.

caption.p: A bimorph cantilever beam.

sec.p: The first case of electromechanical validation is used to validate the actuator model. When a unit voltage is applied across the thickness, the induced internal stresses result in a bending moment that forces the bimorph beam to bend. The theoretical solution to the deflection of the beam is given by Smits et al. (1991)

where hb is the beam thickness and ϕ is the applied voltage. The bimorph beam is discretized into five elements of equal length and a unit voltage has been applied across the thickness. The obtained results have been compared with the analytical solution and the results of Wang et al. (1997) and Tzou and Ye (1996) and presented in Table 3. The comparison of results obtained by using the presented finite element code with solutions reached by Wang et al. (1997), Tzou and Ye (1996), and the analytical solution leads to a conclusion that satisfactory agreements have been achieved.

caption.p: Comparison of static deflection of the piezoelectric bimorph cantilever beam.

sec.p: The second study has been conducted to validate the sensor model. The tip of the bimorph beam is forced to make a deflection of 10 mm. Five equal pieces of separated electrodes are placed on the surface of the beam and the output voltage of each electrode is calculated. The calculated output voltages are presented in Table 4. In Figure 7, the obtained results are compared with the solutions of Sze and Yao (2000). Figure 7 indicates a good correlation between the model of Sze and Yao (2000) and the present model.

caption.p: Comparison of output voltages.
FEM: finite element method.
Output voltages.

sec.title: LQR optimal control
sec.p: In this study, the control system is based on the state feedback control law. In the LQR optimal control, the feedback gains are chosen to minimize a cost function with the form

where [Q] and [R] are symmetric semi-positive definite and positive definite weighting matrices selected to provide suitable performance. The weighting matrices [Q] and [R] are important components of the LQR optimization process since they have influence on the system’s performance. The minimizing efforts of vibration suppression against minimizing the control voltage depend on the relative magnitudes of [Q] and [R]. In general, a larger [Q] puts a higher demand on the control voltage, and a larger [R] adds more limits to the applied control force. Assuming full-state feedback, the control law is given by
where feedback gain [G] is
and [P] is determined by solving the following algebraic Riccati equation (ARE)
Substituting equation (36) in equation (35), the closed-loop dynamics of the system becomes
where [A]cl=[A]−[B][G] is the closed-loop system matrix. The eigenvalues of [A]cl give damped natural frequencies and damping ratios.

sec.title: Weighted-energy LQR
sec.p: The design of an optimal LQR involves finding out such a feedback gain [G] that the performance index, given by equation (34), is minimized. The choice of matrices is the designer’s decision while the optimal gain can be obtained by solving ARE (equation (37)). This is not a trivial problem since the control performance depends on the choice of these matrices. It is common practice to use the trial and error method in order to obtain these matrices. Ang et al. (2002) have proposed that [Q] and [R] could be determined by considering the weighted energy of the system as
and
According to equation (10), the expression [B][G] can be written in the following form
and after replacing it in equation (38), this equation can be decomposed to the following equation
The closed-loop modal damping ratio of the i-th mode from equation (42) can be expressed as follows

In this study, the matrices [Q] and [R] are parameterized according to equations (39) and (40); hence, the optimization problem leads to finding such a combination of parameters α1, α2, and α3 that the closed-loop modal damping ratio of each mode reaches maximum value with a minimization of the maximum applied control voltage. The optimization problem can be written in the following form

where ϕAAjmax represents the maximum control voltage applied to the j-th piezoelectric actuator during active vibration suppression. When parameters α1, α2, and α3 are found, the matrices [Q] and [R] can be obtained by substituting these parameters in equations (39) and (40). After fuzzification, the membership functions of the objectives become as follows

where μdi represents the membership function of the i-th closed-loop modal damping ratio, μϕj is the membership function of the maximum control voltage applied to the j-th actuator, ζdimax represents the maximum closed-loop modal damping ratio of the i-th mode, and ϕAAjmax stands for the maximum control voltage that can be applied to the j-th actuator. Exceeding this maximum allowable control voltage leads to the depolarization of piezoelectric material. The membership functions of objective functions are presented in Figure 8. Finally, the optimization problem can be written in the following form

caption.p: Membership functions of objective functions: (a) i-th closed-loop modal damping ratio and (b) maximum control voltage applied to the j-th actuator.

sec.p: where

represents the membership function of the optimal decision function. The optimization problem given by equation (47) can be solved using the PSO algorithm, applying equations (29) and (30), where α1, α2, and α3 represent coordinates of particles. In further text, this optimization procedure will be named as PSO-LQR. Figure 9 represents the steps in determining the matrices [Q] and [R] by PSO-LQR.

caption.p: Flowchart for PSO-LQR.
PSO: particle swarm optimization; LQR: linear quadratic regulator.

sec.title: Numerical example
sec.p: In this example, the cantilever symmetric laminated beam is considered. The length of the beam is 0.5 m and its width 0.025 m. The beam is made of 10 graphite–epoxy (carbon-fiber reinforced) layers. The thickness of each layer is 0.25 mm and the orientations are (90°/90°/0°/90°/0°)S.The piezoelectric patches are made of PZT5A fiber composite, with orientation of 0∘. Their thicknesses are 0.2 mm. The material properties of the graphite–epoxy layer and lead zirconate titanate (PZT) are given in Table 5.

caption.p: Material properties of graphite–epoxy and PZT.

sec.p: The first five modes are considered as controlled modes. As previously mentioned, mounting piezoelectric A/Ss pairs causes changes in the original dynamic properties and the mass of parent structure. Table 6 shows natural frequencies of the first five modes of the parent beam, maximum value of natural frequencies after mounting A/S pairs, and maximum change of natural frequencies. The mass of the beam without A/S pairs is 0.0434 kg, and when fully covered by A/S pairs is 0.0637 kg; therefore, maximum change of the mass is 46.77%.

caption.p: Natural frequencies of the parent beam, maximum value of natural frequencies after mounting A/S pairs, and maximum change of natural frequencies after mounting A/S pairs.

tr.th: Maximum value of natural frequencies after mounting A/S pairs (Hz)

fn.p: A/S: actuators and sensors; NF: natural frequency.

sec.title: Relations between eigenvalues of Grammian controllability matrix and constraints
sec.p: The aim of this section is to show how constraining the change of natural frequencies and the change of the beam mass affect the eigenvalues of controllability Grammian matrix. This influence is investigated for each controlled mode, and the results are presented in Figures 10 to 14 (for the first mode in Figure 10, for the second mode in Figure 11, for the third mode in Figure 12, for the fourth mode in Figure 13, and for the fifth mode in Figure 14). Figures 10(a) to 14(a) show the relationship between the eigenvalues of controllability Grammian matrix and the change of natural frequency of the corresponding mode, and Figures 10(b) to 14(b) show the relationship between eigenvalues of controllability Grammian matrix and change of the beam mass. For the last three controlled modes, the numbers of the piezoelectric actuators are varied. For calculations of Grammians, a natural damping ratio (ζi) of 0.2% is assumed for each controlled mode.

caption.p: The relationship between the first eigenvalue of controllability Grammian matrix, and (a) NF change of the first mode and (b) change of the beam mass.
NF: natural frequency.
The relationship between the second eigenvalue of controllability Grammian matrix, and (a) NF change of the second mode and (b) change of the beam mass.
NF: natural frequency.
The relationship between the third eigenvalue of controllability Grammian matrix, and (a) NF change of the third mode and (b) change of the beam mass.
NF: natural frequency.
The relationship between the fourth eigenvalue of controllability Grammian matrix, and (a) NF change of the fourth mode and (b) change of the beam mass.
NF: natural frequency.
The relationship between the fifth eigenvalue of controllability Grammian matrix, and (a) NF change of the fifth mode and (b) change of the beam mass.
NF: natural frequency.

sec.p: Observing Figures 10 to 14, it can be concluded that constraining the natural frequency change for a particular mode and constraining the change of the beam mass lead to the decrease of eigenvalues of controllability Grammian matrix that correspond to this mode. Constraining the change of the mass of the beam has greater impact on reducing the eigenvalues of controllability Grammian matrix than the change of natural frequencies. Also, increase in the number of actuators leads to the increase of eigenvalues of controllability Grammian matrix for higher controlled modes, which can be observed in Figures 12 to 14. In other words, if more actuators are used, controllability of the system will be better and control performance will be improved.

< 0 . 25
(in further text denoted as “C4”)

sec.p: The number of A/S pairs is four. The number of randomly generated particles is 100 and the number of iterations is 100. The inertia weights are linearly varied from 1 to 0.5 through iterations. The fulfillments of the constraints, β¯fi and β¯m are set to be 0.95. In order to investigate the influence of different randomly generated initial populations (IP) of particles on final results, four simulations for each case of constraints are performed. For this purpose, the beam is discretized into 50 finite elements. The cognition and social learning factors in the PSO algorithm are set as c1=c2=1.5. The convergences of different IP for each case of the constraints can be seen in Figure 15, showing membership function values of the optimal decision functions versus iteration numbers. Observing Figure 15, it can be concluded that these solutions are converging and final results are within the limits of 10%. Only solutions with the best membership function values of the optimal decision functions for each case of the constraints are considered for further calculations. The sizes and locations of A/S pairs, the membership function of controllability, the best membership function value of the optimal decision functions, and the CPU time for solutions with the best membership function values of the optimal decision functions are shown in Table 7.

caption.p: Membership function values of the optimal decision functions versus numbers of iteration for different IPs: (a) C1, (b) C2, (c) C3, and (d) C4.
IP: initial population.

Optimal locations and sizes of conventionally collocated A/Ss, values of the membership functions of controllability, the best membership function values of the optimal decision functions, and CPU time in the case of 50 finite elements.

sec.p: A more detailed analysis of the effect of c1 and c2 is performed in order to determine how these factors affect the optimality of solution. The effect of the cognition factor (c1) and the social learning factor (c2) on the solution can be seen in Figure 16, which shows the membership function values of the optimal decision function versus the iteration number for each case of the constraints. The factors are varied according to the formula c2=3−c1, in which c1 was varied in the interval [0,3]. One can notice from Figure 16 that when c1=0, the solution converges very fast, within the first 15 iterations, but particles reach a local suboptimal and they are not able to escape from it. In the example of c2=0, the solution does not change from the initial population and the convergence is achieved on the first iteration. The cause of that is the lack of information exchange between the best local and the best global position of a particle. When c1=1 and c2=2, the solution is able to converge to the better region, but again, particles reach local suboptimal. Better results are found for c1=2 and c2=1. The best results are obtained when cognitive and social learning factors are in balance (c1=c2=1.5).

caption.p: Effect of the cognition and social learning factors: (a) C1, (b) C2, (c) C3, and (d) C4.

sec.p: In order to investigate the effect of a different number of finite elements, apart from the 50, simulations for 40, 30, and 20 finite elements were performed as well for each case of the constraints. The obtained sizes and locations of A/S pairs, along with the membership functions of controllabilities, and the best membership function values of the optimal decision functions and the CPU time are presented in Table 8 for 40 finite elements, Table 9 for 30 finite elements, and Table 10 for 20 finite elements. The convergences of membership function values of the optimal decision function for different number of finite elements are depicted in Figure 17. Figure 18(a) presents the best membership values of the optimal decision functions versus number of finite elements and Figure 18(b) presents the CPU time versus number of finite elements.

caption.p: Optimal locations and sizes of conventionally collocated A/Ss, values of the membership functions of controllability, the best membership function values of the optimal decision functions, and CPU time in the case of 40 finite elements.

Optimal locations and sizes of conventionally collocated A/Ss, values of the membership functions of controllability, the best membership function values of the optimal decision functions, and CPU time in the case of 30 finite elements.

Optimal locations and sizes of conventionally collocated A/Ss, values of the membership functions of controllability, the best membership function values of the optimal decision functions and CPU time in the case of 20 finite elements.
Membership function values of the optimal decision functions versus number of iteration for optimal sizes and locations of A/S pairs: (a) C1, (b) C2, (c) C3, and (d) C4.
FE: finite element.
(a) The best membership function values of the optimal decision functions versus number of finite elements and (b) CPU time versus number of finite elements.

sec.p: By comparing results of Tables 7–10 and observing Figures 17 and 18(a), it can be noticed that solutions with a larger number of finite elements have a larger membership function value of the optimal decision function. In other words, the increase in the number of finite elements leads to better evaluated results. The reason for this lies in the fact that the number of finite elements affects the size and position of A/Ss and increase in the number of elements leads to the increase of the possibility of the particle to reach a more optimal solution. However, the increase in the number of finite elements leads to a larger computational effort increasing computational time, which can be observed from Figure 18(b). In further text, only solutions for 50 finite elements will be considered. Figure 19 shows the first five mode shapes, positions, and sizes of piezoelectric patches for these four constraints in the case of 50 finite elements.

caption.p: The first five mode shapes, positions, and sizes of four A/S pairs in the case of 50 finite elements: (a) C1, (b) C2, (c) C3, and (d) C4.
A/S: actuators and sensors.

sec.title: Optimal vibration control using PSO-LQR
sec.p: After finding the optimal size and location of conventionally collocated A/S pairs for four cases of constraints, the next goal is to find an optimal combination of parameters α1, α2, and α3 for maximization of the closed-loop modal damping ratios of controlled modes and minimization of the maximum applied control voltage for the case when the beam is subjected to an impulse load of 10 N at the tip for a duration of 0.1 ms. The allowable voltage of piezoceramic materials is around 500–1000 V/mm. Since the thickness of the actuator is 0.2 mm, the allowable voltage has been taken as 200 V. In general, the maximum value for the closed-loop modal damping ratio can be ∞, but in this article, this maximum is set to be 100% (for values larger than 100%, the structure is overdamped). In all the cases, the optimization process is performed for the first five controlled modes. The dynamic responses have been calculated using the mode superposition technique. The number of randomly generated particles is 20 and the number of iterations is 50. The cognition and social learning factors in the PSO algorithm are set as c1=c2=1.5, and inertia weights are linearly varied from 1 to 0.5 through iterations. The membership function values of the optimal decision functions against number of iterations for four cases of constraints are plotted in Figure 20.

caption.p: Membership function values of the optimal decision functions against number of iterations for PSO-LQR optimization algorithm.
PSO: particle swarm optimization; LQR: linear quadratic regulator.

sec.p: Table 11 shows the obtained closed-loop modal damping ratios, parameters α1, α2, and α3, and the maximum applied voltages to each actuator for four cases of constraints. The matrices [Q] and [R] are obtained by substituting values of parameters α1, α2, and α3 in equations (39) and (40). Before taking this step, one needed to calculate the diagonal matrix of squares of natural frequencies and the dielectric stiffness matrix of the actuators. The matrices [Q] and [R], and the diagonal matrix of squares of the natural frequencies for each case of the constraints are presented in Table 12.

caption.p: Closed-loop modal damping ratios, energy-weighting parameters, and maximum actuator voltages for PSO-LQR control algorithm.

fn.p: PSO: particle swarm optimization; LQR: linear quadratic regulator.

caption.p: Matrices [ω2], [Q] and [R]

sec.p: In order to compare control performances of PSO-optimized LQR (PSO-LQR) with “conventional” LQR, the following weighting matrices are used for calculating feedback gains: Q1=106[I]10×10, R1=[I]4×4 and Q2=105[I]10×10, R2=[I]4×4. The obtained closed-loop modal damping ratios and the maximum control voltage applied to each actuator are presented in Table 13. Comparison of values from Tables 11 and 13 draws a conclusion that the closed-loop modal damping ratios have larger values in the case of PSO-LQR than in the case of “conventional” LQR control algorithm. The effectiveness of PSO-LQR control algorithm in controlling the response of the beam subjected to an impulse load is demonstrated in Figure 21, where controlled tip displacement histories for PSO-LQR and “conventional” LQR control algorithms and, also, the uncontrolled tip displacement history are depicted. Figure 21 clearly shows that PSO-LQR leads to the faster vibration suppression compared to the “conventional” LQR control algorithm. The histories of control voltages applied to the actuator where maximum control voltage appears during active vibration suppression are depicted in Figure 22.

caption.p: Closed-loop modal damping ratios and maximum actuator voltages for [Q]1=106[I]10×10, [R]1=[I]4×4 and [Q]2=105[I]10×10, [R]2=[I]4×4.
The tip deflection of the beam under impulse load in the case of optimal sizes and locations of A/Ss; comparison of PSO-LQR with “conventional” LQR: (a) C1, (b) C2, (c) C3, and (d) C4.
A/S: actuators and sensors; PSO: particle swarm optimization; LQR: linear quadratic regulator.
Maximum control voltage variation under impulse load in the case of optimal sizes and locations of A/Ss; comparison of PSO-LQR with LQR: (a) C1, (b) C2, (c) C3, (d) C4.
A/S: actuators and sensors; PSO: particle swarm optimization; LQR: linear quadratic regulator.

sec.title: Comparative performance of optimal sizes and locations of A/S pairs and randomly generated A/S pairs for PSO-LQR control algorithm
sec.p: The aim of this section is to compare control performances obtained by the PSO-LQR control algorithm for optimal sizes and locations with randomly generated sizes and locations of conventionally collocated A/S pairs. For this purpose, three groups of A/S pairs’ sizes and locations are randomly generated (R1, R2, and R3) for each case of constraints (C1, C2, C3, and C4). The locations, sizes, and membership function values of controllability for randomly generated A/S pairs are presented in Table 14.

caption.p: Locations, sizes, and membership function values of controllability for randomly generated A/S pairs.

sec.p: After that, for each case of randomly generated A/S pairs, an optimal combination of parameters α1, α2, and α3 is found using the proposed optimization technique. The matrices [Q] and [R], the closed-loop modal damping ratios, and the maximum applied control voltage are calculated by using the acquired parameters. The values for closed-loop modal damping ratios; parameters α1, α2, and α3; and the maximum applied control voltages are presented in Table 15. Comparing results in Table 15 with corresponding results in Table 11, it can be concluded that the closed-loop modal damping ratios in the case of optimal sizes and locations are higher and maximum voltage is lower than for randomly generated sizes and locations. Comparing membership function values of controllability for optimal sizes and locations (see Table 7), with corresponding values for randomly generated A/S pairs (see Table 14) and closed-loop modal damping ratio for optimal sizes and locations (see Table 11) with corresponding values for randomly generated A/S pairs (see Table 15), it is obvious that a larger membership function of controllability of a particular mode for random A/Ss does not imply a higher closed-loop damping ratio for this mode. In other words, better control performances are reached when sizes and locations of A/Ss are optimized with the proposed optimization technique.

caption.p: Closed-loop modal damping ratios, energy-weighting parameters, and maximum applied control voltages in the case of randomly generated A/S pairs for PSO-LQR control algorithm.

fn.p: A/S: actuators and sensors; PSO: particle swarm optimization; LQR: linear quadratic regulator.

sec.p: Figure 23 shows controlled tip displacement histories for optimal and randomly generated sizes, and locations of A/Ss for each case of the constraints. The histories of control voltages applied to the actuator, where maximum control voltage appears during active vibration suppression, are depicted in Figure 24. The histories depicted in Figures 23 and 24 verify the results presented in Tables 11 and 15: the presented optimization technique for optimal sizes and locations of A/S pairs shows better control performances compared to the randomly generated A/S pairs for the PSO-LQR control algorithm. In other words, vibration suppression is faster with lower maximum applied control voltage.

caption.p: The tip deflection of the beam under impulse load; comparisons of the results for optimal sizes and locations of A/Ss with randomly generated A/Ss: (a) C1, (b) C2, (c) C3, and (d) C4.
A/S: actuators and sensors.
Maximum control voltage variation under impulse load; comparisons of the results for optimal sizes and locations of A/Ss with randomly generated A/Ss: (a) C1, (b) C2, (c) C3, and (d) C4.
A/S: actuators and sensors.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article presents optimal vibration control by using the particle swarm algorithm and the fuzzy optimization strategy. This optimization technique implies the transformation of objective functions and constraints to pseudo-goal functions through the process of fuzzification. Converting the multi-objective optimization problem into a single-objective one is performed by using the fuzzy decision principle and searching for an optimal configuration with the help of the PSO algorithm. This technique is used to determine sizes and locations of conventionally collocated piezoelectric A/Ss as well as weighting matrices [Q] and [R] for the LQR control algorithm (PSO-LQR).

Taking into account several numerical examples from the study, one finds that the fuzzy set theory implementation enables easy computation, expression simplicity of constraints and objective functions, and avoidance of using weighting coefficients and penalty functions. The PSO technique provided fast convergence, easy implementation, computational effectiveness, and easy handling of the smart composite beam optimization problem.

It has been observed that a larger number of finite elements leads to better evaluated results. Increasing the number of finite elements affects the possible sizes and positions of A/Ss, and results in the solution with the bigger membership degree of optimal decision function. However, the increase of the number of finite elements leads to a larger computational effort with increased computational time. This study shows that the PSO-LQR is much more effective in the vibration control of smart composite beams compared to the “conventional” LQR. Also, using this technique, disadvantages of the trial and error selection of matrices [Q] and [R] are overcome. Moreover, this technique of determining of sizes and locations of A/Ss leads to the maximization of closed-loop modal damping ratios and to the minimization of maximum applied control voltages.

Although this work deals with optimization problems in the case of a laminated beam, taking into consideration all advantages presented here, the discussed optimization technique can be applied for a more complex structure as well as in the cases of truly collocated or noncollocated A/Ss. Also, the proposed optimization algorithm for sizing and location of piezoelectric A/Ss can be considered with conjunction to some other control algorithm.

sec.title: Displacement field and strains
sec.p: The displacement field based on the third-order shear deformation theory of Reddy (Heyliger and Reddy, 1985) is given
or, in a matrix form

where u and w are displacement components in the x and z directions, respectively; u0, w0 are midplane (z=0) displacement and ψx is the bending rotation of midplane, hb is the total thickness of the beam, {u} is the displacement vector, and {ug} is the generalized displacement vector. The bending and shear strains associated with the above displacement field are
where
present generalized bending strains and shear strains. Written in a matrix form, equation (50) becomes
where {ε} represents the strain vector and {εg} is the generalized strains vector. Also, equation (51) can be written in a more suitable matrix form
where [Lu] represents a matrix of differential operators.

sec.title: Piezoelectric constitutive equations
sec.p: Specific electric enthalpy density of a piezoelectric layer (Ballas, 2007) is

where [C] is the elastic stiffness matrix, [e] is the piezoelectric constant matrix, {E} is the electric field vector, and [k] is the permittivity matrix. Therefore, the constitutive equations for each piezoelectric layer can be obtained

where {σ} is the stress vector and {D} is the electric displacement vector. For a one-dimensional composite beam, the width (y-direction) is free of stresses. Therefore, σy=σyz=σxy=0 and εy≠γyz≠γxy≠0. Using the above constraints, neglecting the electric field along the x and y directions (E1=E2=0, i.e. an unidirectional electric field is considered) and taking into account the specially orthotropic laminate that consists of n layers, the constitutive equation for the k-th layer can be written as

where material constants are expressed in principal directions. The relations between the material constants expressed in the principal direction and the material directions for the orthotropic lamina are (Reddy, 2004)
where Θ represents an angle between the material directions of the layer and the principal direction of the lamina.

sec.title: Variational formulation
sec.p: The governing equations of motions are derived using Hamilton’s principle

where t1 and t2 are two arbitrary time instants, δT is the variation of kinetic energy, δH is the variation of electric enthalpy, δW is the variation of work done by external forces, and δUd is the variation of dissipative function defined as
where [Cd] represents the damping matrix. According to equation (54), the variation of electric enthalpy can be written in the following form
where

where [C¯], [e¯], and [k¯] represent the elastic stiffness matrix, piezoelectric constant matrix, and permittivity matrix, respectively, expressed in the principal direction. The variation of kinetic energy, written in terms of mechanical displacements, is
where ρ represents the density of layer.

sec.title: Beam finite element formulation
sec.p: A single mechanical displacement field is considered for all layers while electric displacements are considered for each layer independently. A beam finite element with two nodes is considered here. The linear Lagrange interpolation functions are used for in-plane displacement u0 and for rotation in midplane ψx. The cubic Hermite interpolation functions are considered for transversal displacement w0. The piezoelectric patches are considered as equipotential surfaces. One element has eight mechanical degrees of freedom and nP electrical degrees of freedom, where nP represents the number of piezoelectric layers. The vector of mechanical nodal variables is
and nodal electric potentials are
The elastic element stiffness matrix can be obtained by discretization of the first equation in equation (61) and integration over the surface, as follows
where b represents the width of the beam and
where [Nu] represents the shape matrix given as
in which N10 and N20 are Lagrangian shape functions defined as
and the Hermitian shape functions are
where ξ represents the local coordinate defined as
in which le is the length of the element. The piezoelectric and dielectric element stiffness matrices are
and
where
in which hk represents the thickness of the k-th layer. The element mass matrix that can be obtained from kinetic energy is
The vector of external nodal electrical forces is
where [Kee]A represents the element dielectric matrix of the actuator and {ϕe}AA represents the vector of nodal external voltage applied to the actuator.
